column3: Get rid of the B- grade for 2L's and 3L's! It isn't necessary after 1L, and can be overused by professors.

Columbia Law does not have mandatory B-minuses, yet we still do. The mandatory curve is already the main source of stress for law students and having a grade that places a huge stigma on a student’s record shouldn’t be a mandatory procedure. NYU Law is proud of its collegiality and progressive ideas but still adheres to a practice that hurts students while our peer institutions are moving away from it.
luv you guys <3 (it's ishani lol)

Not only is the grading system unhealthy, but in my opinion, it doesn't even capture how well someone understands the material. For most issue spotter exams, you're encouraged to sloppily write down as much as you can, with little attention to organization and coherence. It's so far removed from the real world, it's ridiculous. And the fact that I feel like I have no control over the outcome gives me a lot of anxiety. OCS and others say that grades don't really matter, but that's not the truth, especially for those that are less privileged and are trying to use better grades to overcome unconscious bias or discrimination.
Having letter grades as opposed to a P, High Pass, Fail, imposes MUCH more stress! Friends at schools without letter grades seem much less stressed and able to focus on more than simply grades.
No grades, like at Harvard and Yale, please.
I like the curve and it’s very generous.  It’s hard to get less than a B-.  That doesn’t seem like a relevant stressor to me.

The innate pressure many law students face, particularly students at the caliber of NYU Law, is in my opinion enough to get rid of extra factors that increase external pressures such as grading and ranking. I appreciate the holistic approach NYU takes to building it's community but switching to a pass/fail grading system would be putting their money where their mouth is. Other "top" schools have switched to this policy and I believe it would help students focus on the material and conceptual aspects of the legal system, not on the grade at the end of the semester. 

In short, we've all worked hard enough to get here, and the vast majority of us will put our own pressure on ourselves to do well, so why not take administrative action and not add additional pressure.
Its unnecessary stress if they really mean it when they say that we are all good enough here

The pressure of doing better than your classmates most of the times makes one lose the objective of learning and gaining knowledge and focus on just competing. The struggle gets tougher to do your learning based on what the professor expects rather than what the subject overall intends to give you. At least in graduate programs this should be avoided. grading is a motivator but grading curve is annoying
No grades! Or have a separate track where as a 1L you can opt into a no-grades program. Make everyone chill the fuck outtttt

Even though I find NYU's environment to be less cutthroat than what I've heard about other schools, the strict curve still creates an unhealthy comparison between students. The focus should be on fostering a supportive learning environment, not on ranking us against each other.
the grading curve is too stressful!! I guess everyone who has earned an A should get an A.
We don't need a curve. We are a good enough law school that everyone is smart/qualified. The curve only creates stress and big firms will still want to hire NYU students.

column3: Really depends on what the grading system is. I can see having a pass/fail system, especially during 1L, GREATLY helping to relieve anxiety and stress surrounding grades. As a 3L pursuing a career in public defense, I now only strive for B's in doctrinal classes, partly because it doesn't matter, and partly because caring too much (and failing to meet those expectations) was negatively impacting my emotional well-being. I have never been in a more toxic academic environment than I have been at NYU, and while there are a lot of factors that contribute to this (mainly the overwhelming racism and classism), our grading system and the competitive environment it creates certainly don't help. Clearer policies on class attendance, and not linking class attendance with grades would also be a HUGE help.

column3: Curious to see if there are already ideas in place or if this is just a general "change the grades" type thing.

I've heard anecdotally that, in law schools without letter grading systems, there becomes significant pressure to network with faculty members. In those schools, because students are less able to distinguish themselves through grades, they resort to other ways of trying to distinguish themselves, such as through recommendations. To me, this suggests that the specific grading system employed by NYU is not the issue; the issue is that legal opportunities are inherently limited and law students are strongly motivated to compete for them.

The pressure of the curve added so much anxiety to my daily life. I felt so reduced to numbers and found it really hard to feel confident going into EIW because I had B's. While I know there are flaws to pass/fail system at other schools, I would really love to be part of a conversation where we can at least start a discussion around these issues. The pass/fail system is also an extreme -- I think even midterms would reduce a lot of anxiety and provide some feedback mechanisms so students know what's working and what's not.

I hate everything about the curve and am happy to rant about it at any time should you wish to contact me.

I graduated from a law school ranked in the top 10 in the world and we did not have the curving system. This facilitated healthy relationships among student, not to mention helped us focus on what we were doing as individuals as opposed to what everyone else in the cohort was doing.

The pressure on grades comes from external sources: jobs and other professional opportunities. Changing the grading only would have those external forces adapt and to expect whatever the equivalent of an A is. And, the broader a grade band is (ie. like High Pass at Harvard), the more opportunity there is for traditionally powerful communities (white men) to advocate for themselves and stand out over minority students. The problem is law school, not NYU grades. Do not change the system.

A lot of the grading seems pretty arbitrary, and even many professors agree that differences between a B+ and A- for example are essentially nonexistent, but those differences on transcripts have real effects on career choices for students

column3: I've been thinking this for two years!

The majority of all law school stress created in 1L is a result of the fact that all of our grades are based in part on our own performance but also in part on the performance of all of the other students in one's section. IT would be much less stressful to know that my own academic success is based only on my own ability discreetly judged on its merits.

The grading system is so clearly a part of NYU (and law school in general)'s abusive pedagogy that's focused on ensuring compliance with authority from students in order to mold us all as future lawyers who don't actually work against injustice in any form. When almost all professors are cis white owning class men, or are people who aren't cis white owning class men but who are still deeply invested in upholding white supremacy and cisheteropatriarchy, the grading system inherently favors students who are white, owning class, men. And because grades can correlate with students' earning potential and access to prestigious jobs, the grading system actually further entrenches racial, gender, and class inequality (which is of course NYU's whole game, but feels important to state it explicitly in the context of grading).

column3: I found the largest source of stress, anxiety and imposter syndrome during finals period came not from the final itself, or in learning the information, but in the needless comparison of one’s study habits to others in a fear of falling behind, in a culture that doesn’t foster learning and knowledge for its own sake but in knowing the material just a bit better than your peers. Employers judge us by our grades, when those grades are not even a reflection of our mastery of a subject  but of our ability to sneak in a point or two more than our peers. If we want to improve our mental health, if we want to build a culture that fosters collaboration, we need a grading system that actually reflects our knowledge, understanding, hard work and skill.
I hate grades and they are a source of stress especially in law school..

column3: I am uniquely unburdened in this area because I know I want to do civil legal services, do not care about "prestige" in the slightest, and have no designs on a fancy fellowship or job in the future. As a result, I have been told about 1000 times that grades will not matter for me. I have taken this to heart! But, I think the general culture and spirit of law school, and the well-being of individual students, would be much improved by getting rid of the forced curve (I think blind grading might still be a good idea, but that's just a gut instinct).

It’s a constant piece of stress in my mind at all times. I would like the thin that I’m going into debt for to not be reflected by a few letters that influence the rest of my career (and arguably my life if we’re being dramatic). Esp because most professors aren’t transparent about their grade and ultimately it’s extremely arbitrary.
They should consider having a pass/fail system like Harvard, Yale, and Berkeley.

column3: Changing the grading system would definitely improve my mental health. Not only would a system without curve change our social dynamics for the better, but it will change the relationship we have with the material we study. Speaking personally, I would much rather have the mentality of learning for the sake of knowledge than learning to perform well in an exam. It’s easier to be happy and motivated when I do something that’s meaningful in itself, than when I’m simply trying to win over others. The system we have right now is archetypical example of a zero-sum game.

it's a toxic head game to constantly be wondering how well I understand the material in comparison to my other classmates rather than in absolute terms. 

here also for complete curriculum overhaul in addition to grade reform. let's take a radical page out of CUNY's book?

Yes - moving to a pass/fail system would remove so much of the pressure from students and allow us to focus on the more important things. It would also encourage more collaboration and less competition.
